body_html:
On Fri, Feb 3, 2017 at 1:21 PM, Yaroslav Bulatov ***@***.***> wrote: so is this expected behavior, or is it a bug in TensorFlow?
Arguably yes/yes, yes/no, no/yes, no/no. :) Many of the samplers don't have analytic gradients due to being dynamic-loop based, eg rejection samplers. We have a reparameterization annotation for each class. However, we should consider at least triggering a warning if backpropping into a non-reparameterizable sampler. Noteworthy example: gradient of Gamma.sample is None wrt to shape param but -x/scale wrt to scale param (where x~Gamma).
…

On Fri, Feb 3, 2017 at 1:21 PM, Yaroslav Bulatov ***@***.***> wrote:
 so is this expected behavior, or is it a bug in TensorFlow?

Arguably yes/yes, yes/no, no/yes, no/no. :)

Many of the samplers don't have analytic gradients due to being
dynamic-loop based, eg rejection samplers.  We have a reparameterization
annotation for each class.  However, we should consider at least triggering
a warning if backpropping into a non-reparameterizable sampler.  Noteworthy
example: gradient of Gamma.sample is None wrt to shape param but -x/scale
wrt to scale param (where x~Gamma).

body:
On Fri, Feb 3, 2017 at 1:21 PM, Yaroslav Bulatov <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> so is this expected behavior, or is it a bug in TensorFlow?
>

Arguably yes/yes, yes/no, no/yes, no/no. :)

Many of the samplers don't have analytic gradients due to being
dynamic-loop based, eg rejection samplers.  We have a reparameterization
annotation for each class.  However, we should consider at least triggering
a warning if backpropping into a non-reparameterizable sampler.  Noteworthy
example: gradient of Gamma.sample is None wrt to shape param but -x/scale
wrt to scale param (where x~Gamma).
